Review title: "I still have the prop!" Massively cool classic, love it!
Review_body: Even if you've merely got a passing fancy for horror, how could you ever read that title and *not* want to watch this movie? More than anything else, it's all about the fun, and I just find it as great and entertaining a watch as it's always been. That's the true test of a classic horror flick, if you can see it over so many times and still it seems fresh, still it offers new insights, still it lends itself to bold and exciting new interpretations! And, you can still go to the bathroom in the middle of it without missing a thing! It's very straightforward and dead easy to get into. I mean, what an angle: A teenage boy who's a big horror fan, he's seen all the movies, read all the stories, and he suddenly finds himself faced with a real monster who's moved in right next door and who soon knows that the boy knows about his true nature - what does he do? It's such a novel concept and one that plays out in such a satisfying way. The atmosphere is amazing, it doesn't ever drag and it doesn't take itself too seriously, not to say there are no scary moments or anything. It's helped a lot by a good cast. William Ragsdale as Charlie was fine, but he was kind of neurotic and boring for me, I thought he was overshadowed even by most of the smaller characters. He played the lead well, I just thought that the role could've been done a lot better and memorable by someone like Zach Galligan, say.. I loved his ditzy mother, she was a hoot! She kept coming out with such funny lines. I absolutely bloody adore Roddy McDowall in this, what a class act. He's simply priceless in his role as Peter Vincent, a meek and unlikely cowardly aged actor who becomes the hero he has played in a string of classic B-movie vampire pictures in his glory days after a graceful character arc in which he gains the courage and "faith!" to face his fear. And Chris Sarandon, he just played his vampiric character to perfection. I love the way he's got the whole charm and seduction thing down, but at the same time he has a certain little odd quirkiness to some of his lines and actions. And he was also perfectly intimidating and wrathful when he had to be. And although you understand how he's gotta go, you never really hate the guy, he's a very likable villain that I could 'dig', and that's half the battle right there at winning the audience of a horror movie over, if the bad guy's interesting and charismatic. I love all of the nifty and gruesome special effects, like the awesomely foreboding mist that swirls around Dandridge's humble abode and sets such a fabulous tone. There's the prosthetics and models of the prolonged sequence where poor strange Evil Ed slowly transforms back into a regular human following an impaling while in wolf form and dies.(Or does he?) I also love the brief but superb animation of the bat, and the little but effective gag of when Amy's dancing and sees a reflection that shows her dancing with thin air. I love that sequence, it's so vibrant and so of its time, it's like someone felt like indulging themselves by incorporating a glitzy music video into their movie and it's really 80s, really corny, and really epic!!! There is also the impressively gooey disintegration of the sexy and mysterious(Demon? Zombie?) Billy Cole, and the spectacular demise of Jerry Dandridge in which he kind of explodes to death. Some of the effects hold up a little better than others, but so what? There's such a charm there sometimes when you know that they had to put it all together themselves, and they clearly had a lot of love for the old vampire movies and the horror genre here, and you just very rarely get that anymore. Still brilliant fun, couldn't have asked for anything better! I wonder if any real vampires ever come to see these films....

Review title: Classic vampire premise meets the glory of the '80s
Review_body: Poor Charley Brewster— he's got a problem. See, the tall, dark, and handsome Jerry Dandridge has just moved into the rundown Victorian house next door; beautiful women come to the house, and are found decapitated by the river shortly after. Oh, and Jerry has fangs. And claws. But nobody believes Charley, not even his goodhearted girlfriend, Amy. And why should they?"Fright Night" is a film that very quietly lurked underneath my radar for years— as an ardent horror fan, it was one film that, when asked about, I'd always say I hadn't seen. People were often surprised, or appalled, even friends who were non-horror fans who had seen it. What took me so long? This is a great flick. The plot is relatively straightforward and takes its cues from classic vampire stories, but its injection with '80s charm lends the film an unusual retro feel that seems both modern and timeless. Writer/director Tom Holland's script is tight and engaging, following the vampire routine while still working toward surprises along the way. Quirky humor is scattered throughout the film, most prevalent in Charley and Amy's lover's spat and Charley's loudmouth single mom who assumes that new neighbor Jerry is "probably gay, with her luck." "Fright Night" is still a horror film by all means, though these unusually charming moments of humor— as well Charley's struggle to convince those around him that he's dealing with a vampire— give the film a lightness that is reminiscent of '80s and early '90s Halloween television films (though it's considerably gorier, showing off some "Evil Dead"-esque special effects in the finale).One of the film's greatest strengths lies its lively performances: William Ragsdale and Amanda Bearse are quintessential '80s teenagers and make one of the most charming pairs in a horror film, while hunky Chris Sarandon lights the screen up as the slick and handsome man next- door who's killing local prostitutes and apparently sleeps in a coffin in the cellar. Roddy McDowall is another great asset to the film, playing the kooky horror television host whom Charley seeks out to help slay a real-life vampire. Overall, "Fright Night" is one of the more delightful '80s vampire romps that is both lightly amusing as well as suspenseful and substantially gory in the decade's fashion. The film's reliance on the textbook components of the vampire film provide it a timeless feel that is charming and engaging. Is it scary? No, not really; but it's got all the makings of a well- rounded teen horror flick with splashes of black humor and a memorable cast that do a remarkable job bringing the script to life (or maybe death). 9/10.

Review title: One of the most entertaining horror movies of the 1980's.
Review_body: Charlie Brewster (William Ragsdale) is a typical teenager, who's average high school student, a nice girlfriend Amy (Amanda Bearse), his goofy best friend Evil (Stephen Geoffreys), a caring mother (Dorothy Fielding) and a good decent house. Charlie finds out that the house next door to him has a new owner, the mysterious Jerry Dandrige (Chris Sarandon) and his roommate Billy Cole (Jonathan Stark). But one night, when Charlie was studying. He was looking on his next door neighbor's window and what it seems to be his neighbor is about to have sex with a beautiful woman. Then suddenly, while Charlie is still looking... he realized that his neighbor has fangs and growing long finger nails. Charlie believes that Jerry is a vampire and his roommate is his guard during daylight. Now Charlie tries to tell his mother, his friends and even a police detective (Art Evens) the truth but no one believes him. Charlie turns to his idol, once B Movie Hammer-type Actor and TV Horror Host Peter Vincent (The late Roddy McDowall) for help but convincing Peter and his friends is a tough thing to do while Jerry is planning to kill Charlie.Written and Directed by Tom Holland (Child's Play, The Langoliers, The Temp) made an enjoyable horror vampire film with game cast and an sharp sense of humour. This is certainly one of the better horror movies of the 1980's and this went on to be instant classic with the fans of the genre. Sarandon is one of the sexier vampires to be seen on the screen and his performance is fun as well. McDowall nearly steals the show as the cowardly yet brave hero, who's faces reality by destroying vampires for the first time. This was a sleeper hit at the box office, when it was first release. A sequel was also produced with Ragsdale and McDowall returning in the second film but it was entirely not totally successful movie. This is probably Holland's sharpest film to date (although I really loved the film, he directed "Thinner"). This has crisp visual style, thanks to Jan Kiesser's (Bad Moon, Dad, Fido) cinematography and Brad Fiedel's (The Terminator, Terminator 2:Judgment Day, Blink) good jazzy electronic score. Make-Up effects, Special Visual Effects and the Production Designs are first-rate as well. Do not miss this one of a kind picture that become an major Cult Classic. Panavision. (****/*****).

Charlie Brewster (William Ragsdale) is a "teen" who's trying to make out with his girlfriend (Amanda Bearse) up in his bedroom one stormy evening while the weekend horror movie on television's "Fright Night" plays in the background. Suddenly, Charlie begins to notice from his window that his new neighbor across the way, Jerry Dandrige (Chris Sarandon) seems to be involved in some shady goings-on. Charlie soon spots him unloading coffins, and romancing a nubile female guest before shockingly biting her throat. Then, Dandrige is seen with his live-in assistant carting away what appears to be a body in a bag. In no time at all, Charlie deduces that his next door neighbor is a real vampire, but nobody will believe him, including his girlfriend and his nerdy buddy "Evil" Ed (Stephen Geoffreys). It isn't very long before Dandrige becomes aware of Charlie's discovery and sets his sights on silencing him. With nowhere to turn, Charlie decides to contact elder film scholar Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall) who has been hosting the local "Fright Night" TV broadcasts in the area and used to be a cinematic celebrity himself in bygone days, having played a Peter Cushing-like vampire hunter in movies before he became a has-been. It's then up to Charlie and "Peter Vincent, Vampire Hunter" to translate film fantasy into reality by attempting to do battle with Jerry Dandrige, who is the real deal.This is easily one of the best of the "modernized" vampire films. It's an old fashioned scary story set against a 1980s backdrop, and it works wonderfully. As the new vampire in the neighborhood, Chris Sarandon is outstanding. He can be suave and charming one moment and deadly fearsome the next. It's an extra special treat to get to see Roddy McDowall here making a strong impression in one of his last iconic parts as the frazzled Peter Vincent. In fact, one of the things I like about the movie is that, unlike today, it was filmed at a time where you could still get away with casting actors who were not currently "box office sensations". So Amanda Bearse (before she became popular from MARRIED WITH CHILDREN) is a refreshing choice as an unconventional leading girl; these days we'd probably have to deal with a Jessica Simpson. As Ed, Stephen Geoffreys can be a little irritating, but at least his character has a sympathetic side to him. It's nice to sense a sort of homage to the Universal and Hammer horror movies of yore, and the whole "late night TV horror host" craze that's lost today. One minor quibble of mine may perhaps be a slight over-reliance on extravagant makeups later in the film, but what the hell --- this is a fun horror movie. ***1/2 out of ****

Review title: Unmemorable 80's flick has its moments, but too few to succeed
Review_body:
Ah Fright Night an homage to vampire films before its time, that not only ends up being anything but scary, but also dreadfully dull and anything but amusing. The film is directed and written by Tom Holland, a horror director at the time, not the Spider-Man star. Holland would later move to directing and writing the horror classic Child's Play in 1988, which is actually quite surprising in my opinion. It isn't that Child's Play is some great horror film, no, it's actually more funny than scary- but what was so enjoyable about that film is superbly the opposite of this one, that being, it was fun to watch. Not only that, but it was entertaining, and this film clearly has no intention of trying to be so, or frankly, trying at all. It's a mess, the actors are rather mediocre, and besides a few moments where a supporting cast member or to actually try to put effort into this lazy script, it stays that way all the way throughout. The worst performances the film has to offer is that of Stephen Geoffreys who plays Evil Ed, which is the weirdest and most out of play sidekick character I have ever seen on film. The other performance that is absolutely horrendous is Jonathan Stark, who is so bad, its honestly quite funny at times. Besides the incredibly plot holes filled script, and lack of any consistent tone whatsoever, the film also has trouble keeping its pacing in tact, as well as deciding what it even wants to be. It spends half of its time pretending to be this 80's campy teen comedy about sex and relationships or whatever, and then moves on to this weird dull horror, which can be I guess dark at times, but is honestly quite hard to take seriously. It has a good look throughout I suppose, and some cool special effects, but they are often masked by the dullness of the direction or the odd amount of generic 80's music blaring through the speakers. In the end, Fright Night is not worth the effort, nor your time. Its an overrated vampire flick that hasn't aged well, and honestly, if you're looking for something somehow more worth your time, try Teen Wolf. At least it was entertaining.
My Rating: 3/10

Fright Night is an incredible horror that's fun, tense and an 80s movie in all the right ways. William Ragsdale and Amanda Bearse are both great. Chris Sarandon is an effortlessly suave villain, Roddy McDowall is perfect and Stephen Geoffreys is really good, if a little annoying at times. Tom Holland's direction is fantastic, it's well filmed and fast paced. The special effects are really impressive and the music by Brad Fiedel is amazing.
Not bad. Not bad at all. I can see why this film has such a strong cult following. The plot summary of the film doesn't do it justice. A must of you're a fan of horror or vampire movies or both.

Fright Night is simply 80's vampire movies at their greatest. It goes along with The Lost Boys in terms of horror, gore, and fun. No depressing, sparkly, romantic crap here. Here we see Ragsdale discover his neighbor is a vampire. Of course nobody believes him and he's soon driven mad. Luckily he forms an alliance with a reluctant TV vampire hunter. As I said, Fright Night is a fun movie, which always raises a chuckle, but it also has some disgusting effects. I'm talking real practical stuff, with some of the most painful deaths and transformations you can imagine. This stuff is so much more creative with prosthetics and the like. Computers can easily make a body melt, or turn a wolf into a man, here some truly creative visuals make these things a reality. Sarandon is excellent as the charming vampire, and it's nice to see him go along with trying to prove he isn't a vampire. It shows him as a man that would rather keep his secret than enter a battle to the death. Ragsdale does the usual not-believed-kid routine, but he makes it work. McDowall stole the movie for me. He plays an out of date TV star given a chance to live out his pretend life. The threats are real, and the climax steadily grows. You do have to suspend some belief in terms of how the characters respond, but if you love the 80's, vampires, and movies that knew how to be fun no matter what their subject, you need to see Fright Night.

Review title: Scary and Funny In Equal Doses
Review_body: Vampire movies are almost by definition parodies, the only variable being the degree and the quality of the parody elements vs the scare elements. "Fright Night" (1985) is neither the best parody nor the scariest thriller, but it has the distinction of being the all-time best mix of the two. Both its parody and its scare elements work extremely well and their juxtaposition really makes the film worth seeing. "Fright Night's" production design will remind you of "Gremlins", a contemporary film, but the spirit of the film is more along the lines of Polanski's "Fearless Vampire Killers". Average suburban teen Charley Brewster (William Ragsdale) accidentally discovers that his new neighbor is an evil vampire. The vampire is not particularly discrete, not bothering to pull the window shades and disposing of a victim in a plastic garbage bag. Charley unwisely goes public with his accusations. This tips off the vampire that his teenage neighbor may be a threat. But he is still safe because nobody believes vampires are real. Not only does no one believe Charley but the vampire discovers that Charley's girlfriend Amy resembles his lost love, which makes her a target. Amy is played by a young Amanda Bearse ("Married With Children"), which you will probably find a bit disconcerting for several reasons but it is kind of interesting to see her as a hot teen love interest. In desperation Charley goes Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall), the host of the local television show called "Creature Features". The special effects are excellent and not overdone. Dorothy Fielding who plays Charley's airhead mother should get special mention for her excellent performance. One of the running gags during the first half of the film is her failure to find anything suspicious about her new neighbor or his nighttime activities. Then again, what do I know? I'm only an inner child.

Director Tom Holland has been known to make some wicked horror films. He is best known for producing Child's Play (1988) but Fright Night is no different. It has its freaky and creepy moments too. However there are parts to this movie that could have been tweaked. And it's not like they're totally bad choices because it is a good movie. But those parts could have been replaced with something better if the producers were given the chance to.Fright Night is your typical teenage horror genre movie. A boy notices something supernatural and tries to tell the public about it and no one believes him. Worst of all, now that supernatural force is out to get him so no one will know the truth at all. In this case, the supernatural something that this boy notices is a vampire living next to his house. That plot line is creepy enough as it is. I don't think anyone would feel comfortable if that were to happen to him or her. The teenage boy, Charlie Brewster, is played by William Ragsdale and he's one of the flaws in this film. Ragsdale is good as the kid that he is, but I can't help but not feel any pity for him. Why? Because it was he who got himself into trouble with the vampire. He was spying on the vampire while feasting on his prey. Sorry but you don't go spying on others and expect to get away with it. Besides I really didn't care for his character either because of the nasally voice that he had. However, the vampire played by Chris Sarandon gives a redeeming performance for this movie. Sarandon's acting is so good that it really is hard to tell sometimes whether the vampire he's playing, is mean-spirited or just misunderstood.Getting help for Brewster is not easy until he decides to call upon a renowned Vampire slayer, Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall). Funny enough, even for him, Vincent has to confront with himself that Brewster's case is serious. The special effects are good too. It is fairly surprising for a 1985 film. The only other drawback this movie has, is that it never frightened me and it's not because the visuals weren't scary. It's that the movie never reached the psychological level where things can become truly terrifying and I never felt it. But nonetheless, this film is very creepy.The scares may not be all there but it will definitely evoke some good chills. Much of which the credit goes to Sarandon for his believable execution as a vampire.

Geekish teenager Charley Brewster (William Ragsdale) lives his charmed suburban life, befriended to the wacky Evid Ed (Stephen Geoffreys) and squeamishly dating Amy Peterson (Amanda Bearse). His idyllic youthful existence collides with the grim realisation that his next door neighbour Jerry Dandridge (Chris Sarandon) is in fact a man with distinguished tastes in human blood. Unable to convince anyone about this revelation. Charly seeks the aide of Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall), the host of late night C-class horror movies "Fright Night", whose owes his limited fame to being a vampire killer.With a script that didn't invite much in terms of plot-hole afterthought, Tom Holland grapples his basic premise by the next and delivers a disgustingly funny vampire movie with some memorable quotes, wicked charm and three star quirky characters in the form of neurotic whiny Evil Ed, timid self-absorbed Peter Vincent and the vintage Jerry Dandridge. Despite the painstakingly obvious flaws somewhat reminiscent Roger Corman-like disregard to logic, "Fright Night" has grown somewhat of the cult status, imprinting various quotes and scenes into mainstream pop-culture. Whatever your tastes the 1980s had a peculiar ability of delivering rare treats, which worked not only despite its flaws, but to some extent thanks to them. Nowadays movies seem so polished, that they avert the potential for creative disaster, thus no longer being able to deliver the kind of fractured horror gems. Verging somewhere in 'so-bad-its-good' territory, enhanced by some chilling visual effects (the disgusting morphing of the period is just so much more effective then CGI).

Well, since movies involving vampires are usually quite lame, I find this one to be a good one. It is interesting to notice how different horror movies used to be in the eighties; nowadays horror movies are extremely scary and are supposed to frighten you big time, whilst in the that decade they used to be mixed with fun, in a "Ghost Busters" style. William Ragsdale is a good actor and he is unintentionally funny throughout all the movie. One thing I must congratulate is the make-up team; the actors became really ugly when portrayed as vampires. Stephen Geoffreys' character begins normal, but once he becomes a vampire, he turns into a creepy monster that almost scares the spectator. It's impossible to not notice how many homoerotic scenes involving the vampires exist in this film; director really wanted to show that. All in all, I haven't seen the remake yet, but I will surely enjoy if it has the same feeling this version has.

Fright Night is a classic 80's horror film. It's a shame that it's taken me so long to actually see it, I always passed it off thinking it was a crappy low rent horror movie. Boy was I wrong, here is a film that mixes comedy, horror and great special effects.The film is about a young kid who loves vampires (yet somehow doesn't know about garlic and stakes until someone tells him?) and finds out that his neighbour is exactly that. When no one believes him he takes it upon himself to put a stop to the vampire's vampire ways.Compared to the other classic 80's vampire flick The Lost Boys, Fright Night doesn't stand a chance, it simply doesn't have as strong characters, scenes or entertainment. BUT, Fright Night is still an entertaining cheesy film that should be watched by people who love the genre.The special effects are pretty sweet, specifically when one character is staked and is stuck mid transformation between man and wolf. Although the actor who played this character has an incredibly annoying laugh that will get on your nerves.Chris Sarandon is the vampire in question, you may remember as Humperdinck from The Princess Bride. He does a great job at being seductive and cool all while still being menacing in his looks. Roddy McDowall is the vampire slayer (on TV) and is hilarious in this role, the man is terrified to be in this situation, but gets the job done when he has to.This is Tom Holland's best film, he came close with Child's Play, but Fright Night is a film that you can watch more then once. The camp in Fright Night is perfect and everything works so well. Fright Night may not be as good as Lost Boys, but you will not be disappointed with it, it's just a fun film to watch.

Review title: Still a decent vampire flick 15+ years later
Review_body: I managed to re-catch this on AMC and still find Fright Night a decent vampire flick. It doesn't go the easy route of turning its vampire antagonist into a punk-types who's "with it" in the latest goth-style (see Lost Boys, Dracula 2000, Dusk til Dawn, etc.), but has Chris Sarandon show why Dracula could have been viewed as a seductive, evil yet believable presence whether Drac is in the 19th century or the 20th. Instead of doing a "modern" vampire, Sarandon plays a character who shows why vampires are timeless seductive evil and don't have to be up with today's styles to pull it off.There's also lots of little injokes, from Dandridge whistling "Strangers in the Night" to his obsession with apples (harking back to Eden and the serpent and the apple), to his fixation with clocks (wouldn't you?) to the vague kind of bisexual relationship he has with a wacko Jonathan Stark as Billy Cole.Roddy McDowell is the other half of the show, managing to be impressive, petty, egotistical ("What could be more important then an interview?" - "Oh, well I could see how a boy's life _might_ be more important."), desperate ("How _much_ money?"), all too humanly flawed, and heroic. McDowell flashes through all of these emotions sometimes in the space of seconds, and shows why he was always a class act.The rest of the cast is okay. Amanda Bearse must have fun looking back at this, her only attempt that I can remember at being a female romantic lead. A little of Stephen Geoffreys goes a long way, and ditto for William Ragsdale, who I never really have liked. He spends way too much time in full-blown panic mode here to be very sympathetic - you end up wondering what kind of idiot this guy is.It's pretty much those six actors for the most part - everyone else is pretty much forgettable. Sure there's some weird moments (Charley and Amy discussing their aborted sex life 20' away from Charley's mom), and the "Boy who cried wolf" thing goes on _way_ too long.Overall, though, I'd still recommend this movie to those who want to see that vampires don't have to be punk to be impressive.

Review title: There are good reasons to be afraid of the dark.
Review_body: I watched ''Fright Night'' two days ago and I had a surprise : the movie is good! I expected it to be one of those silly movies where I wouldn't give more then 6, but I liked it so much, that now I consider to be one of the best vampire movies from the 80's that I already watched, along with ''Lost Boys''. It's funny to see Amanda Bearse, the famous ''Marcy D'Arcy'' from ''Married with Children'' in the role of the teenager Amy(specially because she was almost in her 30's)and this is the first and only movie I watched with her in a different role from ''Marcy''.The plot: Charley Brewster is a big fan of horror movies, and is always watching ''Fright Night'', one of his favorite TV shows about vampires and other monsters. So, when his new and handsome neighbor Jerry Drandridge arrives, Charley immediately discovers that the guy is a vampire. Things starts to get bad for Charley, when Jerry discovers that Charley knows not only his 'secret', but also that he is killing a lot of women to satisfy his appetite.Charley tries to talk to other people about Jerry, but the problem is that nobody believes in a single word that he says. Now, the poor Jerry needs to find a way to be safe from being killed by Jerry and showing to his girlfriend Amy, his friend Ed and his hero, Peter Vincent (the host of a late-night horror show on TV) that he is in fact, right.

I can get why it could be a classic to some. But I thought it was slow and didn't like the cast. Special effects were mostly good and creepy for that time. But I struggled through watching it, and did it in two gos. Which never happened before...

Review title: 'TV myth' has its roots. The truth is far darker...
Review_body: What's brave about this (and still holds up today) is its willingness to poke fun at pop-culture obsessed youth while recognising that without such 'historians', the fabled lore of the past would have found itself extinguished long ago. "Fright Night" was the inventive precursor to the ironic horror hits of the following decade, such as "Scream". It's made by the geeks who love the genre to serve as some sort of justification, implying that one day being a 'geek' might just save your life...It really is great fun for a movie fan to see Roddy McDowell - himself something of an acting legend in the sci-fi arena - taking on the role of a veteran performer forced to use the skills of his craft in a real-life situation. It's vindication for every armchair observer who gets themselves involved in another reality. Like "Rear Window" with vampires in it, "Fright Night" is a hair raising ride and one of the slickest, most enjoyable horror-comedy efforts that the '80's managed to give us.

Teenage B-movie buff William Ragsdale becomes convinced that new neighbour Chris Sarandon is a vampire responsible for a spate of brutal killings. Only when best pal Stephen Geoffreys has become Sarandon's slave and girlfriend Amanda Bearse has also fallen under his spell does Ragsdale succeed in enlisting the help of "fearless" TV vampire hunter Roddy McDowall to end Sarandon's reign of terror.There have been quite a few actors playing lead vampire/Dracula, and doing justice to the role - Bela Lugosi, Christopher Lee to name a few - but I think Chris Sarandon is up there as a really menacing, cool, and cold blooded, yet suave neck biting fiend, and he basically dominates the film, adding the fright to the night, whilst Roddy MacDowell, in a delicious turn as a Van Helsing-like figure ( but only on TV), lends the humour.Fright Night is a unique mix of horror and comedy as well as a commentary about new neighbours, that you never who is moving in your neighbourhood ( it could be a vampire), the plot is solidly paced, and from the killer opening where our hero ( a horror loving teen) spots Sarandon bite someone's neck the film doesn't falter and it has your whole attention. The appearance of McDowell as the TV horror actor revs up the film a notch, making it even more enjoyable, especially for the fact that he's a coward really and doesn't believe in vampires, let alone can slain one in real life. William Ragsdale is excellent as is Amanda Bearse and Stephen Godfreys.In a decade where slasher films was rife , Fright night, with its mix of genres, is refreshing, has great FX, and is hugely entertaining. It's my favourite horror film, and the soundtrack is deliciously 1980's (AOR/ melodic rock bands like Autograph, Joe Lamont, and White Sister feature). An 80's horror gem.

Review title: A long time ago... when vampires still wore shirts and drank blood.
Review_body: Another film with a video cover that looked just a little too much for 12 year old me when released, meaning I missed out on this minor gem until I was too old to appreciate it.For some reason I always mixed up Fright Night with Tales from the Crypt, meaning I expected one of those compendium films with three or four shorter stories instead of the full fledged Vampire film that I ended up with.In extremely familiar circumstances to many other films (The Burbs, House) Fright Night finds a young school student named Charlie – a horror film fan – dealing with the realization that perhaps the new neighbours might just be vampires, not especially good timing seeing as it happens on the same night that his long time girl Amy decides to "give herself up" to him.Unlike EVERY OTHER TEENAGE BOY IN HISTORY Charlie takes asks for a rain check from Amy even after she's assumed the position – so to speak – just because he saw people carrying a coffin across the yard next door. Speaking for myself at that age smacking me across the back of the head with a shovel wouldn't have distracted me one iota, I guess Charlie was made of different stuff.Over the next few days Charlie sees and hears things that elevate his threat level, meanwhile corpses start piling up. He decides that the new neighbour is indeed a vampire, only no-one believes him, not his Mum, not the cops, not even dear old Amy.So he does exactly what any lad should do and asks his whiny mate for help and advice. The whiny mate has a nasal high pitched and frankly offputting voice, he also laughs like an idiot and seems to snort at the end of most sentences. For some reason he remains just as annoying and obnoxious and they justify keeping him in for the remainder of the film. There always seems to be the dorky sidekick in these sorts of films – I just can't remember one so clearly abhorrent. The one worthwhile thing this dipsh*t tells Charlie is that vampires can't enter your home unless you invite them into it – Let the Right One In also sees the vampire having to deal with the same issue.All should be sweet but you should always think about the innocence of your Mum, that very night she not only lets the guy in, she invites him to dinner! The neighbour is a suave, smooth talking, good looking man named Jerry Dandridge, at least to Mum and everyone else. But as soon as he and Charlie are alone or if no-one is looking he lets Charlie see the real him, and openly tells him that he is coming to gettim.So the cops, GF, loser mate and even Mum have failed him so Charlie turns to the one guy who surely must come through, a late night host of crappy horror movies called Price Vincent (get it?). ultimately Amy comes back onside – which is important as she must play a key role in the vampire's masterplan, and Charlie, the old hack and Amy must battle the evil undead for control of both Amy and their lives.Aside from one scene this is all reasonably tasteful and even low key in stretches, far from some of the more over the top antics of say From Dusk Til Dawn or other 80s horror films. There was one particular scene though where they obviously went balls-out to make an impact.With minimal gore or massive makeup effects there isn't much to report on that front, but there are a couple of memorable decompositions and a cool – if awkward – transformation sequence. I found Fright Night refreshingly low key and old school, where perhaps many other films of the era might have let things degenerate into a schlockfest they spaced out the early kills and confrontations and allowed things to build up to a short but impactful finale.Final Rating – 7 / 10. Not the best horror movie of the era, but alongside The Gate a solid 80s effort and an ideal non-threatening intro to the genre for a newbie or a movie marathon.

Review title: He must've been a Vampire Fruit Bat.
Review_body: Fright Night, Lost Boys and Near Dark are the holy trinity of 80s vampire flicks. And arguably three of the best vampires movies of all-time. Just recently I returned to this piece of 80's horror gold and I have to say, I enjoyed it just as much as the first time I saw it.Fright Night is about a kid named Charlie Brewster who accidentally discovers that his new neighbor, Jerry Dandrige, is a vampire. The movie is about Charlie and friends setting out to destroy the vampire. But Mr. Dandridge is no slouch and is more of a threat to them, then they are to him.Besides being one of the best 80's horror films, I think it's also one of the best movies of the entire 1980s. The movie is full of great performances, especially Chris Sarandon as Jerry Dandrige and Roddy McDowall as TV Vampire Slayer Peter Vincent. It has fantastic make-up effects that are sorely, sorely missing from today's horror flicks. And it also combines a great feel of horror with a realistic touch of comedy and drama. The best and funniest aspect to the movie for myself is how they portray the vampire character. I won't spoil it for you, but the guy enjoys wearing very "tata" clothes, eats "fruit" all the time, and has a live-in roommate. This movie is classic! Fright Night has a sequel that some say is equally as good, but I wouldn't be one to say that. But, I do enjoy the sequel and definitely think it's worth a view. If you're a fan of horror and vampires, this is a must see flick. Welcome to Fright Night baby!

Soooo stereotypical for this kind of movie in the mid eighties. It is a little hard to picture Amanda Bearse as the teenage love interest after her coming out as a lesbian (I still think she is cute, just not for guys I guess). Roddy McDowall is so good as the campy late night host of horror movies who gets fired, but helps out the young Charlie Brewster when push comes to shove. Brewster is a courageous young teen who steps up to the plate when no else believes him about the bloodsucker living next door to him. Chris Sarandon plays the very chic vampire who plots to suck everyone he can. When Roddy doesn't see any reflection in his cigarette case things start to change. When Roddy hits the turned best friend with the cross, burns his fore head but doesn't kill him, the turned friend threatens revenge by by the Master. The physical display at the disco is not in keeping with the whole staying under the radar of most vampire movies. After all if they know you exist they can come up with a way to kill you. But of course all ends well, kind of maybe, almost.

Three stars from "Maltin" for this piece of horror-schlock ? (the quotes around "Maltin" bespeak my unproven suspicion that he employs legions of underpaid would-be critics as writer/drones) Hearing that this much-heralded flick was to be shown on AMC, I alerted my son. After viewing it, I apologized to him. The effects are dated. The plot - at least as presented - is not credible. The acting is bargain basement (I sympathize with Roddy MacDowell, having to make something of this dreck). Particularly grating is Stephen Geoffreys as Ed Thompson; his performance really causes the gorge to rise. All in all a massively overrated item, which could only be lauded by the bubble-gum-and-rap-music set.

(57%) A refreshing change of pace to the mass of typical slasher movies that the period threw out which this actually mocks at one point. The plot is simple stuff centred around a vampire moving in next door to a typical suburban family, the teenage son gets suspicious after witnessing some goings on with some late night coffin dealings, so he contacts TV horror host Roddy McDowall to help him out. Its good points involve the likable cast, solid direction, and some great practical effects. And even though this isn't one of my favourite of the 80's horrors, it's still a cut above the average lot and should be tracked down by all vampire film fans.

Fright Night is a well-done treatment of the standard teen horror film. The teenage son of a single mom learns that their new next-door neighbors are a couple of vampires. Of course, he can't convince a soul, not his girlfriend, the cops, his mom, or his best friend. They believe he's crazy. In desperation, he turns to a recently fired ex-horror film actor, who grudgingly helps him in his battle against the vampires.Well acted, (Roddy McDowell is great as the over-the-hill actor), the movie hits the right balance of humor and horror that makes this an entertaining rental.

I'm not a horror buff, and real horror fans would consider this ridiculously weak tea, but I thought that it was an excellent campy 80s horror flick. It's the "Rear Window" of vampire movies with decent special effects, mild violence and gore by today's standards, and a clever plot line. The acting is very good throughout and it keeps moving from beginning to end. This film is just the ticket for those of us who like our horror on the very light side. If that includes you, you should consider giving this one a shot.

Review title: A true classic horror vampire flick better than remake!
Review_body: Fright Night (1985) is an awesome true classic vampire horror film that is written and directed by Tom Holland him self. I love the remake, but I just love the original much better. In here you have monsters, a real vampires and werewolves in it. Chris Sarandon did a wonderful job as Jerry Dandridge a vampire by night. I love the make up and I love how they were portraying a vampire in this movie. Evil Ed (Stephen Geoffreys) is a turned werewolves at the end of the film and he is staked by Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall). Fright Night (1985) is one of my favorite vampire horror flicks, I love vampire movies and this film is for me. The remake is a good film, but they aren't portraying real monsters and werewolves like they do in this movie. I am pretty sure if the new movie would portrayed such a monsters, werewolves like in here, I am pretty sure the movie would be better! The end was perfect and awesome how Charley and Peter are fighting Jerry, I love how Vincent and Charley are smashing in all the basement windows, allowing the sunlight to hit Dandridge. Using a mirror, they reflect the sunlight and finally manage to kill Dandridge by blasting him with the rays and he bursts into flames and within seconds his body is reduced to dust and bones. That scene was awesome!I love Roddy McDowall as Peter Vincent the great Vampire Killer! Seriously this movie kick ass! Roddy McDowall kicks ass in this slasher vampire film! I love everything about this film, that it is in it! My all time favorite vampire movie ever, a classic, the remake doesn't even come close to matching it. Chris Sarandon was perfect as Jerry Dandridge the next door neighbor vampire, nothing will ever change my mind about this one, no vampire movie since this one has ever matched it, movie or series!! Fright Night is a ultimate classic a classic film that I will always cherish it to death! The special effects are great in this one. This film not only has vampires, werewolves and monsters in it, it also has a virgins, it has Roddy Mcdowell in one of his best performances. It has Prince Humperdink/Jack Skelenton as the baddie. It is quotable, self-aware way before Joss Whedon/Kevin Williamson, and funny as hell. The weakest link, although she still gives a very good performance, is Amanda Bearse AKA Marcy Darcy from Married with Children as the sexpot (could be bonus if you are so inclined), object of desire. It's hard not to look nor listen to her, without waiting for an Al Bundy insult, but there is some consolation when she "turns". Watch it and love it, this is what comedy-horror is all about. This is a great movie. I wouldn't say it scared me to death but it's good and creepy, it's one of those movies you can watch over and over again. GREAT FILM! Our heroes are a motley group of characters, the straight-laced boy next door who no one believes, the bookish girl crush who is coveted by all, the monster-fan geek, and a most wonderful touch with Roddy McDowall playing a washed-up horror actor similar to character actors such as Peter Cushing/Christopher Lee/Vincent Price. Bottom of line I love this film, it is one of my favorite Vampire horror slasher films, I also love the remake, tough it even can't hold a candle to this film. Meet Jerry Dandridge. He's sweet, sexy, and he likes to sleep in late. You might think he's the perfect neighbor. But before inviting Jerry in for a nightcap, there's just one thing you should know. Jerry prefers his drinks warm, red and straight from the jugular! It's Fright Night, a horrific howl starring Chris Sarandon as the seductive vampire and William Ragsdale as the frantic teenager struggling to keep Jerry's deadly fangs out of his neck. Only 17-year-old Charley Brewster (Ragsdale) knows Jerry's bloodcurdling secret. When Charley can't get anybody to believe him, he turns to TV horror host Peter Vincent (Roddy McDowall), who used to be the "Great Vampire Killer" of the movies. Can these mortals save Charley and his sweetheart Amy (Amanda Bearse) from the wrathful bloodsucker's toothy embrace? If you love being scared, Fright Night...will give you the nightmare of your life. That is the main plot in the remake they don't even mentioned Jerry's last Surname. Fright Night is a 1985 American horror film written and directed by Tom Holland and produced by Herb Jaffe. It stars William Ragsdale, Chris Sarandon, Roddy McDowall, and Amanda Bearse. I love this film to death! It is my favorite best horror slasher film, the rating I am giving tot his film is 10/10. This film deserves it! Tom Holland thank you for so beautiful wonderful horror vampire film, big cheers and thank you!

Eighties youth movies... don't you just hate 'em? Surely one of the worst things in society; a cultural glitch that will return to visit you in Hell, along with Country music and corduroy trousers.Fright Night is typical of the period, and contains all the requisite elements: A club scene with eighties music and fashions - (hello braces!) - check; Some sub-soft porn titillation, including a gratuitous breast shot set to a drum machine - check; Excessive gore and ropey make-up effects - check; Irritating ugly nerd sidekick - check; Wit and understatement - sorry, you're not on the list.Fright Night is a spoof of horror movies, with Roddy McDowall (a fun performance, but can't save the film) as a TV host who is scared of vampires in real life. So that when William Ragsdale finds his neighbours are vamps, McDowall is too terrified to help. There are some brief mentions of other genre films, though Roddy having a justified pop at Friday the 13th does not a satire make. And while it predates The Lost Boys by two years and sort of inspired Buffy et al., this is hardly worthy of praise. Not very funny, not very scary, and not very good, Fright Night is a weakly directed, bog-standard "youth" pic that drags on too long at just 105 minutes.There was a sequel (imaginatively titled "Fright Night Part 2") three years later, though you don't really expect me to see that as well do you? 4/10.Post-Script, 11/9/2008: Happened to catch this film again forgetting that I'd seen it, much less commented on it. I can only assume I was in a REALLY bad mood when I wrote the above, as I found it fun and gave it 6/10 this time. And despite my earlier protestations, I HAD watched the sequel, and gave that a 5.

If you are like me and like your horror films to be heavy on the fright and minimal,if any blood and gore,then Fright Night will be right up your alley.It has all the elements that a true horror film is supposed to have.There is just nothing scary about blood,therefore it doesn't need to be seen at all.There is very little blood to speak of here,which is ironic considering that we are dealing with vampires,who of course thrive on it.This is a big part of the appeal of the film for me.Also,Chris Sarandon makes a very convincing,very menacing and seductive vampire,perhaps the best this side of Bela Lugosi.Overall,a very small percentage of the horror films I have viewed over the years actually do their job.This is one of the few.Well done!

Review title: Respecting all vampire conventions that Tom Holland made one of the coolest movies of the '80s
Review_body: The 70s and especially the 80s were rich moments for Hollywood horror cinema. In addition to the two masterpieces of the genre, The Exorcist (1973) and The Shining (1980), famous franchises took their first steps and some of the most revered villains were born: Michael Myers, Freddy Krueger, Jason Vorhees are some whose names terrified young teenagers of yore. Such is the importance of this period that, nowadays, we are attacked with a flurry of remakes and reboots of those same villains of yesteryear.The first scene in the film is brilliant: a huge moon and a wolf howl already show that nothing good is coming; we then see a typical suburban neighborhood in the United States and the camera in a very well executed traveling focuses on the house of Charley Brewster (William Ragsdale), who is currently making out with his girlfriend Amy (Amanda Bearse) - he doesn't seem to be enjoying it much anymore. Who prefers to draw her boyfriend's attention to the program that is on TV. But Charley proves to be even more stupid because the girl is semi-naked, but he prefers to keep investigating with binoculars the new residents of the house next door. It's even understandable since there are two men carrying a coffin into the house! Meanwhile, several murder cases are advertised on TV, and the situation is further complicated when Charley realizes that one of the murdered people was in the house next door the day before! It would be a simple suspense plot if the killer wasn't a vampire!Playing James Stewart in Rear Window, Charley starts to watch over everything going on in the house next door and its owner Jerry Dandrige (Chris Sarandon), who has just moved in along with his friend Billy Cole (Jonathan Stark). One night, he realizes that Dandrige has fangs and is about to bite a girl. Charley is even more terrified when he realizes that Dandrige has seen him! Charley's fight now is to prove that his neighbor is a vampire, which obviously no one believes! His mother, his girlfriend and even his best friend Ed Thompson, or Evil Ed.Director Tom Holland brings to the viewer a horror film different from those that permeated the 1980s. Seeking inspiration in Hitchcock, using the voyeuristic aspect present in 'Rear Window' (1954), and in films of the 1930s genre, Holland delivers to its viewers a beautiful film, without, however, losing the trash aura present in the best decade of horror in cinemas. The Hour of Amazement (Fright Night, 1985) is the type of film that, in addition to establishing the view of the world through the eyes of a young protagonist, manages to transform all that horror plot into an analogy to the fears and questions that run through his mind. With that, he rescues a peculiar atmosphere, of nostalgia, present in several productions belonging to that decade, evidenced by always garish scenarios and a still naive action. Among other genres, horror became a means for directors and screenwriters to leave heroism and courage to the teenager; it was increasingly common to see them as protagonists, destined to face evil with the weapons and fearlessness they had at their disposal.Certainly, it's a somewhat corny concept, even though it was precisely that which gave some 1980s films a charming aura of nostalgia. In A Hora do Amazto, there was already a charm for the old-fashioned (even for the time), denounced both in dialogues and in the characterization of certain characters. Whether in the known artifices to annihilate a vampire (from crucifixes to wooden stakes) to the scenic construction of their dwellings, the fascination for the infamous mythology of nocturnal entities was evident, at a time when it was undergoing major changes. It is possible to visualize in Jerry Dandrige clear allusions to Count Dracula, from the sad and passionate face to a remarkable elegance in his gestures; but the visit to the literary work of Bram Stoker is felt not only through his antagonist, but also through the curious figure of the decadent television host Peter Vincent, an amusing mixture of Van Helsing and Bela Lugosi.According to rookie director Tom Holland (who would come to direct another classic "Killer Toy"), the desire was to make The Boy Who Cried Wolf updated for the 80s. And as he still liked vampire stories, he decided to mix it all up in a great script. But in the '80s, vampire movies weren't all that hot. In a funny but tragic scene, Peter Vincent, being fired from the command of the TV show, vents to Charley: Do you know why I was fired? Why young people today no longer believe in vampires. All they want to know is killers in hockey masks chasing innocent girls. The reason for all of this, Tom Holland explains in interviews that one of the reasons the genre has declined is that there were a lot of vampire movies made in the 1950s, but that no one could modernize them. For this movie, he was determined to respect all the conventions of a traditional vampire story - coffins, no reflections in the mirror, vampire being invited by the owner and all the rest - but always putting them in a contemporary context.And it was respecting all vampire conventions that Holland made one of the coolest movies of the '80s, which taught a whole new generation the rules of how to identify and kill a vampire. The film also has great special effects and makeup all in charge of Richard Edlund's Film Corporation, the same as Ghostbusters. The producer created extensions for Dandrige's fingers as well as masks that made the actors downright scary. One of the best sequels is when Evil Ed reverts to his human form shortly after turning into a wolf and being defeated by a very lucky Peter Vincent. This is all without any CGI, just makeup effects interspersed with camera cuts.There are two reasons for the success of Fright Night: the first is the setting in the suburb where Charlie Brewster (Ragsdale) discovers that his new neighbor Jerry Dandrige (Sarandon) is a vampire. From the howl of a wolf in the opening to the predominance of shadows and fog in Jan Kiesser's photography, director and screenwriter Tom Holland manages to balance the tone of disbelief nicely with the discovery that there is a menacing and dangerous leech next door. From the opening minutes, Holland surprises with a safe and vigorous debut in the direction. The references from horror television shows work, and art direction John DeCuir Jr. Succeeds in recreating the sanctuary of passionate vampire hunter Peter Vincent (McDowall), in Bella Lugosi's scattered posters, crucifixes and scattered ornaments throughout the house. Furthermore, the direction gradually confirms the monstrous nature of Jerry discovered by Charlie's appalled voyeuristic gaze. The signs are clear: neighbors carry a coffin to the basement, the newspaper reports the death of two people, one Charlie had seen the day before, and one of the neighbors, Billy Cole (Jonathan Stark) is seen painting the windows of the house.Looking at Fright Night these days, you can see that the film has hardly aged. Aside from the horrible fashion of the 80s and a sequence that takes place in a disco where an amusing (but dated) song by Devo is heard - making a point of showing all the power of the synthesizers of the time - almost nothing has aged. The effects are still very good and oddly enough, better than many current movies. The performances are also memorable, Roddy McDowall is perfect as an apparently arrogant and cowardly ex-star who when he sees that vampires exist even chicken out not to mention that he always makes a point of reliving the glories of the past by commenting on the films in which he participated. And don't belittle of course, McDowall's work would be even more interesting if they were actually chosen a veteran horror actor to play himself. Have you ever thought how interesting it would be to have a Peter Cushing cast? At the other end we have Chris Sarandon shining as the seductive vampire Jerry Dandrige, who at times even has the grimaces of Hammer actors doing a delicious tribute.Everything here evokes the spirit of a decade lost in time, of an innocence that was still patent, whether through the immense difficulty of the leading couple in having their first night of love (since today's teen films have long since surpassed this range), or even the clear conflicts between credibility and skepticism. It is common for every child to immerse themselves in fantasy, in the belief in everything that adults are not able to see; this is how Charley's adventure takes place, in the confidence in his own eyes and in the challenge of convincing others of the veracity of that situation. In this way, the spectator was able to arouse empathy for the trajectory of that boy, since there, above all, there was no more than a teenager wanting to be heard and taken seriously.Its considerable success would break, if only momentarily, the public's excitement towards slasher movies, which left aside the massacres committed by serial killers to focus its attention on the maddening battle of a young man against strange creatures. Fright Night is an open film, which ends with reticence, whether because of the opportunity to make a sequel (which would be released three years later) or even because of the evidence that there is still more to tell after that. The point is that, in one way or another, the red eyes that peek into the darkness right at the end betray the same as the mysterious opening scene, because the full moon that appears in the symphony of howls makes the message clear: we will have a long night ahead.

Review title: "'And Like A 'GHOUL' Neighbor, 'STAKE' Farm Is There!"
Review_body: Part of the "vampire renaissance" that took place in the '80's, FRIGHT NIGHT was one of three films that made vampires hip and chic with the teen set, (THE LOST BOYS and NEAR DARK were the other two.) It was also the brainchild of ingenious writer/director Tom Holland, who would also give the horror world a demented little "Good Guys" doll named Chucky...Charley Brewster (William Ragsdale) is a typical horny teen with two passions in life: getting to third base with his girlfriend Amy (future MARRIED WITH CHILDREN star Amanda Bearse) and watching the late night spook show FRIGHT NIGHT, hosted by former horror legend Peter Vincent, (Roddy McDowall in top form). Wellll...make that THREE passions. A recent series of brutal murders involving young women has Charley convinced that his 'playa' of a neighbor, the handsome and charming Jerry Dandrige (Chris 'PRINCESS BRIDE' Sarandon) is in fact a 'creature of the night.' The problem for both Charley and his night-prowling neighbor is...Charley's RIGHT.Holland and the entire cast have fun taking all of the conventions of a John Hughes saga and taking a Dracula-sized bite out of them: teens dealing with hormones, relationships, their favorite quirky habits and hobbies, and of course, with your single mom having a romantic interest in a new guy. Who just so happens to be a vampire.Charley tries at first to convince his late-night horror hero Peter Vincent that there's more afoot in the house next door than the usual hanky-panky. After he's persuaded with a little monetary 'consideration', Vincent relents and decides to prove to Charley once and for all that there are no such things as vampires. That's when Peter suddenly finds that, to his own surprise and horror, some things do have basis in both 'reel' AND real life after all, and must make a decision whether or not confronting them is possible...or even worth it!This is one of those horror movies that still plays well even now. McDowall's schtick is dead-on as he simultaneously satirizes and salutes the work of old horror stand-bys like Vincent Price, Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee. Ragsdale and Bearse are engaging leads, but the real scene-stealers here are Jonathan Stark as Jerry's "best bud" and familiar, Billy Cole, and Stephen Geoffreys as "Evil Ed" Thompson, Charley's best friend/sidekick, whose role as a teen outcast leads him to a painful and tragic end. Or does it?But a vampire movie is only as good as its lead monster, and Sarandon is more than up to the challenge, giving a career-making performance. (Holland would have him back in a more 'subdued' role in CHILD'S PLAY.)The visual effects (Richard Edlund) and makeup (everyone from Steve Johnson to Greg Cannom pitching in) were state-of-the-art at the time, and though some of the "boo!"- worthy scares haven't dated very well, since most movies have used them a trillion times by now, there's still one or two sequences guaranteed to make you wet yourself a little.FRIGHT NIGHT makes a great springboard for a "triple-night" at the movies, should you team it up with THE LOST BOYS and NEAR DARK.

One more film about vampires, yeeeha! This time they merged blood-suckers and the typical 80's teenage horror stuff. It looks more like a parody than like a true horror movie, and I don't think anybody (not even the actors) took this project very seriously (neither did I!!).So the B-series lovers will enjoy "Fright night", but the only scary thing in this movie is the soundtrack (say your prayers before listening' to it). What else could I say about it? Man, it doesn't even deserves the compulsory 10 lines.*My rate: 3/10

Review title: Light-hearted monster pic with terrific cast
Review_body: FRIGHT NIGHT Aspect ratio: 2.39:1 (Panavision)Sound format: Dolby StereoUnable to convince anyone that his new neighbor (Chris Sarandon) is a vampire, a desperate teenager (William Ragsdale) summons the help of a reluctant TV 'horror host' (Roddy McDowall) to confront the monsters in their midst...Bridging the gap between 'traditional' horror and contemporary, effects-driven blockbusters, Tom Holland's enjoyable potboiler saves most of its fireworks for the second half, when the forces of Good and Evil square off against a barrage of monsters and mayhem, courtesy of Richard Edlund's extravagant visual effects. Ragsdale and love interest Amanda Bearse are saddled with stock juvenile characters, but Sarandon relishes his role as the vampiric predator, and McDowall is superb as a faded horror star whose old-fashioned values are shaken to the core by his confrontation with modern evil.Some observers have discerned a homoerotic subtext in Ragsdale's obsession with his handsome, vampiric neighbor, and also in Sarandon's pursuit of Ragsdale's high school buddy (Stephen Geoffreys, later known as 'Sam Ritter', star of gay adult movies like VIRTUAL STUD and SEX ON THE BEACH), but homophobes are reassured that this particular subtext isn't allowed to interfere with the slam-bang pyrotechnics. Geoffreys employs a range of tics and mannerisms which will infuriate some viewers and endear him to others, but his final sequence - one of the best in the entire movie - is charged with genuine emotion (rendered even moreso by McDowall's extraordinary, wordless performance on the sidelines), and the 'death rattle' which accompanies his departure is one of the creepiest sound effects this reviewer has ever heard! Followed by FRIGHT NIGHT PART 2 (1988).

Review title: So much better then the remake.
Review_body: This is another one of those examples where the classic is way better then the original. The remake completely changed the story line I would not even really call it a remake.The acting in this one is good and the special effects are actually creepy instead of that CGI crap.
